p: Ensure that SSLÂ is used when transmitting credentials and never unencrypted connections.
Using SSL prevents the credentials from beingÂ identified or tampered with as they are transmitted over the network.

Verify that a dedicated SSL-enabled server is used for the authentication component of your application. Ensure that your application's authentication component runs on a dedicated subdomain and a server that accepts only HTTPS traffic. Disallowing unencrypted HTTP connections will prevent accidental or malicious unsecured connections. Check that the server uses valid SSLv3 certificates that have been signed by a trusted certification authority. Disallowing lower SSL versions, such as SSLv1 and SSLv2 will ensure that weaker encryption methods can not be exploited by an attacker.The following URL should connect and prompt for login credentials:
An HTTP URL to the same server and component should either be disallowed or redirect to its HTTPS counterpart:
Identify forms that send credentials. Forms are defined by a <form> tag in the HTML document, such as the one below:
Forms that include credentials usually, but won't always, include an input field with a TYPE attribute set to password:
Ensure that form data is sent using HTTPS. Examine the ACTION attribute of the <form> tag and ensure it posts to an absolute URL path and includes HTTPS in the URL, as shown below:
Using Secure Socket Layer (SSL) over HTTP requires the following steps:
Create a certificate request. Using your hosting server or OpenSSL, generate an SSL certificate request. Example:

Present the request to a Certification Authority (CA). If all conditions for obtaining an SSL certificate are met, the CA will produce a new SSL certificate based on the certificate request. Because the requirements for obtaining an SSL certificate depend on the Certification Authority, consult with the Certification Authority in regards to the administrative steps necessary for obtaining such certificate.
Install the certificate. Consult with the hosting server's documentation on how to install the SSL certificate.

Ensure credentials are sent over SSL. Place the authentication portion of your application on a dedicated subdomain. Configure the server to accept only HTTPS traffic for the authentication subdomain. Ensure that form posts containing credentials are sent over HTTPS. This is accomplished by using absolute URL paths in the action field. Example:
In the following snippet, the credentials are transmitted over unprotected HTTP. This allows an attacker to easily steal credentials from sniffed traffic.
In the following snippet, the credentials are transmitted over HTTPS. This makes it difficult for an attacker to steal credentials from sniffed traffic:

Ensure that your application's authentication component runs on a dedicated subdomain and a server that accepts only HTTPS traffic. Disallowing unencrypted HTTP connections will prevent accidental or malicious unsecured connections. Check that the server uses valid SSLv3 certificates that have been signed by a trusted certification authority. Because the requirements for obtaining an SSL certificate depend on the Certification Authority, consult with the Certification Authority in regards to the administrative steps necessary for obtaining such certificate.
    
    
      
        Install the certificate. Consult with the hosting server's documentation on how to install the SSL certificate.

html:
What to Check For

Ensure that SSL is used when transmitting credentials and never unencrypted connections.

Why

Using SSL prevents the credentials from being identified or tampered with as they are transmitted over the network.

How to Check

  1. Verify that a dedicated SSL-enabled server is used for the authentication component of your application. Ensure that your application's authentication component runs on a dedicated subdomain and a server that accepts only HTTPS traffic. Disallowing unencrypted HTTP connections will prevent accidental or malicious unsecured connections. Check that the server uses valid SSLv3 certificates that have been signed by a trusted certification authority. Disallowing lower SSL versions, such as SSLv1 and SSLv2 will ensure that weaker encryption methods can not be exploited by an attacker.

    The following URL should connect and prompt for login credentials:

    https://login.example.com/myapp/login

    An HTTP URL to the same server and component should either be disallowed or redirect to its HTTPS counterpart:

    http://login.example.com/myapp/login

  2. Identify forms that send credentials. Forms are defined by a <form> tag in the HTML document, such as the one below:

    <form method="POST" action="https://login.example.com/myapp/login">

    Forms that include credentials usually, but won't always, include an input field with a TYPE attribute set to password:

    <input type="password" name="pass" size=25>

  3. Ensure that form data is sent using HTTPS. Examine the ACTION attribute of the <form> tag and ensure it posts to an absolute URL path and includes HTTPS in the URL, as shown below: 

    <form method="POST" action="https://login.example.com/myapp/login">

How to Fix

Using Secure Socket Layer (SSL) over HTTP requires the following steps:

  1. Create a certificate request. Using your hosting server or OpenSSL, generate an SSL certificate request. Example:

    # Generate private key
    openssl genrsa -des3 -out privkey.pem 2048 
    # Generate certificate request using private key
    openssl req -new -key privkey.pem -out cert.csr

  2. Present the request to a Certification Authority (CA). If all conditions for obtaining an SSL certificate are met, the CA will produce a new SSL certificate based on the certificate request. Because the requirements for obtaining an SSL certificate depend on the Certification Authority, consult with the Certification Authority in regards to the administrative steps necessary for obtaining such certificate.

  3. Install the certificate. Consult with the hosting server's documentation on how to install the SSL certificate.

  4. Ensure credentials are sent over SSL. Place the authentication portion of your application on a dedicated subdomain. Configure the server to accept only HTTPS traffic for the authentication subdomain. Ensure that form posts containing credentials are sent over HTTPS. This is accomplished by using absolute URL paths in the action field. Example:

    <form method="POST" action="https://login.example.com/myapp/login">

Problem Example

In the following snippet, the credentials are transmitted over unprotected HTTP. This allows an attacker to easily steal credentials from sniffed traffic.

<html>
  <head>
    <title>login form</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <form method="POST" action="http://login.example.com/myapp/login">
    <input type="text" name="user" size=25><br>
    <input type="password" name="pass" size=25><br>
    <input type="submit" name="submit" value="log in">
    </form>
  </body>
</html>

Solution Example

In the following snippet, the credentials are transmitted over HTTPS. This makes it difficult for an attacker to steal credentials from sniffed traffic:

<html>
  <head>
    <title>login form</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <form method="POST" action="https://login.example.com/myapp/login">
    <input type="text" name="user" size=25><br>
    <input type="password" name="pass" size=25><br>
    <input type="submit" name="submit" value="log in">
    </form>
  </body>
</html>

Java Communication Security Guidelines

  • Encrypt Communication Links
  • Protect Sensitive Data Over the Network
  • Use SSL
  • Use SSL for All Sensitive Pages
  • Use SSL When Transmitting Credentials
  • Use Valid SSL Certificates
  • Use Only Strong SSL Algorithms
  • Do Not Cache Sensitive Data
  • Do Not Place Sensitive Data in Parameters

Java Communication Security Checklists

  • Communication Links are Encrypted
  • Sensitive Data Is Protected Over the Network
  • SSL Is Used
  • SSL Is Used for All Sensitive Pages
  • SSL is Used When Transmitting Credentials
  • Valid SSL Certificates Are Used
  • Only Strong SSL Algorithms Are Used
  • Sensitive Data Is Not Cached
  • Sensitive Data Is Not Placed in Parameters

Java Communication Security Testing

  • How to Test for Network Credential Sniffing Bugs in Java
